Spending days gathering information and then dispensing Intel into a concise and compelling read could be both rewarding and tiring. As for Paul Finebaum, American sports television and radio personality, the sword is double-edged. Finebaum is a leading sports writer, primarily in the southeastern United States.

Bio (age) of Paul Finebaum

Born July 26, 1955 in Memphis, Tennessee. Paul was the second child born to his parents – Gloria and Benjamin Finebaum. His full birth name is Paul Alan Finebaum and he has an older brother, a sister named Pam Finebaum. Paul attended Christian Brothers High School in his hometown of Memphis. He also enrolled at the University of Tennessee and graduated with a degree in political science in 1978.

His journalism career started from college where he covered student government affairs for the college newspaper. Two years out of college, in 1980, Paul moved to Birmingham where he began working for the Birmingham Post-Herald as a journalist and columnist. Between 1980 and 2000, some of Paul’s works were major stories like the firing of Auburn University coach Terry Bowden, the recruiting of Alabama basketball player Buck Johnson, and other stories. Paul left in 2001 to write a column with the Mobile Press-Register.

In 1985, his radio career took off when he started working for WAPI-FM. While working for WAPI-FM, Paul worked as a commentator. He ran the morning show, Mark and Brian Radio Show and after that Paul hosted his own show on the same station. His contribution to the world of television broadcasting has been many. From 1998 to 2002, he was sports director of WIAT-TV. On the side, he worked with WVTM-TV NBC 13 and ABC 33/400 as a co-host on some shows.

Finebaum began a working partnership with major sports news brand, ESPN, where he played a major role in Roll Tide/War Eagle, a documentary. His relationship with ESPN saw him appear regularly on network shows such as Sports Center, Olbermann, and others. He received a Sports Emmy along with fellow contributors to the show, College GameDay.

In addition to the career he had made behind the microphone and the cameras, Paul Finebaum also has a gift for writing. His most famous work is the popular I Hate… series. The series includes books with the same title with the phrase “I hate it.” One such work includes I Hate Michigan: 303 Reasons Why You Should Too. He wrote a book about the show, HarperCollins. When the book was finally published, it made The New York Times bestseller list and remained there for the next five months. The very first edition of the book sold 150,000 copies. Paul has also published other works such as Finebaum Said -published in 2001,Auburn: The Postcard Book published in 1996 among others.

Net salary

Paul Finebaum has been lucky enough to work at the pinnacle of sports journalism for decades. He also has many works written to his credit. While we may not know his exact salary, we do know that his net worth is estimated at $2 million.

Family – parents, siblings

Paul was born in Memphis, Tennessee, but his family had moved there from the Big Apple, New York, shortly before he was born. Benjamin Finebaum, Finebaum’s father, was an optometrist who died in 1971. Paul’s mother, Gloria Filderman Finebaum, worked as a clerk at the IRS office in Memphis to support her family after her husband’s death. Paul Finebaum had an older brother, his sister Pam.

Married Life – Woman

Paul was married but there is not much detail about marital and family life. He married his wife, Dr Linda Hudson, in 1990 after they met at the Birmingham compound where they lived. It is not clear whether the couple has or had children from their marriage.
